author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: Are the Giants and Jets Watchable Yet?
description: We enlisted two experts — one locally focused, one nationally — to offer readers their opinions.
content: This season, we’ve enlisted two experts — one familiar with the ins and outs of New York’s football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst — to answer an essential question as a service to readers: Are these teams good yet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Offers Thousands of Visas to Foreign Truckers to Ease Driver Shortage
description: The move reflects growing alarm within the government about a disruption to supplies that has prompted panic buying and, in some cases, caused fuel to run out at gas stations.
content: LONDON — Responding to an escalating crisis, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain reversed course this weekend and offered thousands of visas to foreign truckers to combat a driver shortage that has left some supermarket shelves empty and caused long lines at gas stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael R. Strain
title: Republicans Are Playing a Dangerous Game With Debt
description: They know the borrowing limit must be raised, one way or another.
content: Senate Republicans say they believe the nation’s borrowing limit should be raised, and don’t want the United States to default on its financial obligations — they just don’t want any part in helping Democrats get it done. “This could not be simpler,” the minority leader, Mitch McConnell, said on Thursday. If the Democrats “want to tax, borrow and spend historic sums of money without our input, they’ll have to raise the debt limit without our help.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaly Soto
title: Germany chooses a new Parliament.
description: On Sunday, Germans will choose a new Parliament, which will ultimately determine who succeeds Chancellor Angela Merkel at the helm of the European Union’s most populous democracy. More than 60 million people are eligible to vote in this election.
content: On Sunday, Germans will choose a new Parliament, which will ultimately determine who succeeds Chancellor Angela Merkel at the helm of the European Union’s most populous democracy. More than 60 million people are eligible to vote in this election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Tonys are back. Here’s what to expect and how to watch the show.
description: This year’s Tony Awards are taking place, live and in-person, starting at 7 p.m. Eastern on Paramount+, followed by a 9 p.m. concert on CBS.
content: It’s been a long, long time since Broadway last held a Tony Awards ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: Before ‘Hamilton’ and ‘In the Heights,’ Lin-Manuel Miranda had ‘Freestyle Love Supreme.’
description: The show received a special Tony Award for creating something different: an improvised musical performance whipped up anew every night.
content: The vast majority of the Tony Awards granted on Sunday are honoring shows that have been rehearsed to an excessive degree — every step onstage precisely choreographed, every note and line repeated to perfection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Théoneste Bagosora, a Mastermind of Rwanda Genocide, Dies at 80
description: Mr. Bagosora was convicted of genocide for ordering a massacre in the capital and the killing of top officials, including the prime minister.
content: KIGALI, Rwanda — Théoneste Bagosora, a senior Rwandan military figure who was one of the masterminds of the Rwandan genocide, died on Saturday in a prison in Mali. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: The Limits of ‘My Body, My Choice’
description: Prioritizing individual freedom is not enough to bring about a just society.
content: At a protest against vaccine mandates, a hospital worker told New York’s Livingston County newspaper: “If you want it? Great. If you don’t? Great.” She continued: “Choice is where we stand. If you want it, we’re not against it. That’s your choice.” Those I know who have refused to get vaccinated or wear masks have echoed this same idea. They assure me that they aren’t telling anyone else what to do but that this is a matter of personal choice. They are doing what they think is best for themselves and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: With Abortion Largely Banned in Texas, an Oklahoma Clinic Is Inundated
description: The new law prohibits abortions after about six weeks, a very early stage of pregnancy. Many women are now traveling out of state for the procedure.
content: OKLAHOMA CITY — On a windy Tuesday morning, the parking lot outside a small brick building on the Southside of Oklahoma City was filling up fast. The first to arrive, a red truck shortly before 8 a.m., was from Texas. So was the second and the third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: ‘The Morning Show’ Remakes Itself. Again.
description: The topical news drama, which reoriented its first season in response to the #MeToo movement, was forced by the pandemic to rewrite Season 2 as well.
content: The second season of “The Morning Show,” the starry Apple TV+ series about a “Good Morning America”-style talk show, was six weeks into filming in March 2020 when everything suddenly stopped cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Labour’s Leader Struggles to Emerge From Boris Johnson’s Shadow
description: Competent but low on charisma, Keir Starmer has yet to give British voters a clear reason to support the main opposition party, critics say.
content: LONDON — If Prime Minister Boris Johnson went to one extreme with his pithy 2019 election slogan — “get Brexit done” — the leader of the opposition Labour Party, Keir Starmer, has gone to the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele, Vimal Patel and Michael Levenson
title: At Least 3 Killed and 50 Hurt in Amtrak Derailment in Montana, Officials Say
description: The derailment, involving eight cars of the Empire Builder train, happened near Joplin, Mont., on Saturday afternoon.
content: At least three people were killed and 50 others were injured after an Amtrak train derailed in Montana on Saturday afternoon, setting off a frantic response by rescuers who scrambled to extricate passengers from cars, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Usyk’s Win Is a Plot Twist for Boxing’s Heavyweight Division
description: Oleksandr Usyk’s defeat of Anthony Joshua complicates the division but creates more opportunities for big fighters to face one another.
content: Late last week, the path to a single, undisputed heavyweight boxing champion looked simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: German Election Heralds Messier Politics and Weaker Leadership After Merkel
description: Preliminary results indicated an outcome so tight that it could take months of talks to form a new government at a critical moment for Europe.
content: BERLIN — After 16 years of Angela Merkel as their chancellor, Germans scattered their votes across the political spectrum on Sunday in the election to replace her, a fractured return that heralds a messier political era in Germany and weaker German leadership in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: What to watch for on Sunday.
description: Sixty million people are eligible to vote in the German national election on Sunday.
content: Sixty million people are eligible to vote in the German national election on Sunday. There won’t be a new government that night, or the next day — it could take the rival parties weeks or even months to settle on a coalition with a parliamentary majority. But the ballots are tallied quickly, and the new shape of Germany’s political landscape is likely to be visible within hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: As Covid wave pushes up demand, Costco limits purchases of toilet paper and water.
description: The retailer cited an uptick in demand because of the Delta variant and a shortage of truck drivers.
content: Last year, a frantic run on toilet paper that left store shelves bare across the United States became a symbol of the panic that seized Americans in the early days of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Intrigue Deepens at U.N. Over Myanmar and Afghanistan
description: On the final day of the General Assembly’s most important annual gathering, no one is expected to speak for Myanmar, but the envoy of Afghanistan’s ousted government may yet take the podium.
content: No official representing Myanmar will speak on Monday, the final day of the United Nations General Assembly plenary, U.N. officials said, in an apparent 11th-hour compromise that would deny a global platform to the country’s warring democratic and militarist factions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: A British Men’s Wear Designer With Jamaican Roots
description: Bianca Saunders started her namesake fashion label when she was 24.
content: Name: Bianca Saunders
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: A Debt Deadline Looms
description: The Fed indicated it was planning to slow down its purchases of government bonds as soon as November. And food delivery workers in New York gained protections.
content: The Federal Reserve indicated on Wednesday that it might soon ease measures it put in place to support the economy since the depths of the pandemic downturn. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said the central bank’s monthly purchases of $120 billion in government-backed bonds “still have a use, but it’s time for us to begin to taper them,” and indicated that it might slow the program as early as November. Meanwhile, half the Fed’s policymakers said they expected to raise interest rates next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: The Price of Balloons
description: Zachary David Levy saves the day.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I’m delighted to see Zachary David Levy back in the New York Times Crossword puzzle! This is Mr. Levy’s second puzzle, after his stellar tribute puzzle to the Notorious R.B.G. that ran last June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Bobby Zarem, ‘Superflack’ and Maker of Stars, Dies at 84
description: As a spirited impresario of public relations, he promoted entertainers, films and the “I Love New York” tourism campaign.
content: Bobby Zarem, the exuberant press agent who fulfilled his childhood fantasies by catching rising stars and promoting them to stellar careers, died early Sunday morning at his home in Savannah, Ga. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Eyes on the English Channel as a Migrant Crisis Brews.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 26, 2021.
content: “There is this history of welcome and also of defense. Both are ingrained — it just depends on which buttons are pressed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: The Marines Reluctantly Let a Sikh Officer Wear a Turban. He Says It’s Not Enough.
description: While other armed services allow some religion-based exceptions to dress standards without problems, the Marines insist that even small deviations can threaten the force’s effectiveness.
content: Almost every morning for five years, First Lt. Sukhbir Toor has pulled on the uniform of the United States Marine Corps. On Thursday, he also got to put on the turban of a faithful Sikh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: The Maps That Steer Us Wrong
description: Misleading maps are leading us astray.
content: Too many of our digital maps are sellouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Are These the Next Cool Sunglasses?
description: The emerging brand Sunnei went all-in on goggles on Milan Fashion Week’s third day.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Freed From Guantánamo, but Still in Limbo 15 Years Later
description: Abu Bakker Qassim, a Uyghur from China, was dumped in Albania after the U.S. concluded he was not a terrorist, as Chinese authorities had maintained. The only country that wants him is China.
content: TIRANA, Albania — Accused by the United States military of being a terrorist in league with the Taliban, a devout Muslim man from western China spent four years imprisoned at Guantánamo Bay before being cleared and then dumped in Albania 15 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German officials expect record mail-in ballots.
description: BERLIN — German election officials are expecting mail-in ballots to break records in Sunday’s federal election. At least 40 percent and possibly a majority of ballots will arrive by mail, according to Georg Thiel, head of the agency in charge of counting the votes.
content: BERLIN — German election officials are expecting mail-in ballots to break records in Sunday’s federal election. At least 40 percent and possibly a majority of ballots will arrive by mail, according to Georg Thiel, head of the agency in charge of counting the votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: An Immersive, Absurdist Show to Remember
description: Takeaways from a Marni experience that brought new life to Fashion Week.
content: MILAN — Finally, a kind of catharsis. An event that — like the 150th-ranked Emma Raducanu winning the U.S. Open or Chloé Zhao getting to direct a Marvel movie — kicked open the door after months of mostly isolation to shake us out of complacency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: America’s Need to Pay Its Bills Has Spawned a Political Game
description: Republicans and Democrats have long sparred over raising the debt ceiling. But this time, the odds are growing that the U.S. could default.
content: WASHINGTON — For nearly two decades, lawmakers in Washington have waged an escalating display of brinkmanship over the federal government’s ability to borrow money to pay its bills. They have forced administrations of both parties to take evasive actions, pushing the nation dangerously close to economic calamity. But they have never actually tipped the United States into default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Can a Mantra Make You Run Faster? This Olympic Medalist Has No Doubt.
description: “I love these words and phrases because usually they start in practice or in conversation,” Courtney Frerichs said. Those words and phrases helped her win a silver medal.
content: This is a story about Courtney Frerichs, who turned in one of the surprise performances of the Tokyo Olympics. But really it is a story about mantras, because who Frerichs is and what she managed to accomplish this summer are all about the words she has been repeating to herself for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 27, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Tonys Winners List: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Gets 10 Awards
description: Here are the winners of Sunday night’s Tony Awards.
content: The Tony Awards were back for the first time since 2019 and after the longest shutdown in Broadway history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jay Sandrich, Emmy-Winning Sitcom Director, Is Dead at 89
description: Acclaimed for his work on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “The Cosby Show,” he also made a crucial casting decision about “The Golden Girls.”
content: Jay Sandrich, a prolific sitcom director who won Emmy Awards for the two series he worked on most often, “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “The Cosby Show,” died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Audra McDonald has six Tonys. Tonight she’s hosting the awards ceremony.
description: She has won more competitive Tony Awards than any other performer, and tonight, when she is a nominee for the ninth time, she is presiding over the awards ceremony.
content: Audra McDonald has won more competitive Tony Awards than any other performer, and tonight, when she is a nominee for the ninth time, she is presiding over the awards ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: How China Plans to Avert an Evergrande Financial Crisis
description: Control of the banking system gives Beijing the tools to stop a broader collapse, officials believe, while censorship and police powers can stifle protests.
content: BEIJING — In any other country, the sudden collapse of a corporate titan with more than $300 billion in debt would send shock waves across the economy. Headlines would blare. Banks would shudder. Investors would panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: U.S. Routs European Team to Take Back the Ryder Cup
description: Collin Morikawa’s birdie putt on No. 17 secured the half-point the U.S. team needed to clinch its victory against Europe on the way to a 19-9 rout.
content: HAVEN, Wis. — The first tee on a Ryder Cup Sunday is usually a place of high tension. But not on this Ryder Cup Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: This Lab Charges $380 for a Covid Test. Is That What Congress Had in Mind?
description: Insurers say it’s price-gouging, but a law left an opening for some labs to charge any price they wished.
content: At the drugstore, a rapid Covid test usually costs less than $20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: With 2 Losses, Clemson Is a Far Cry From Its Enduring Playoff Standards
description: Clemson has had some tight moments. But before this season, the Tigers would usually come through.
content: RALEIGH, N.C. — For more than a decade, it has been hard to imagine the Clemson Tigers being uncomfortable in the position they were in Saturday night: trailing North Carolina State in double overtime, fourth-and-5 at the 20-yard line in front of a frothy, capacity crowd on the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 3 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Justin Herbert and the Chargers want a Chiefs rivalry, Josh Allen is still Josh Allen and the Steelers aren’t winning their bet on Ben Roethlisberger.
content: The No. 1 takeaway from Week 3 in the N.F.L.? These new-look Los Angeles Chargers possess precisely what it takes to beat the Kansas City Chiefs: guts. An endless supply of guts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: In-person turnout is lower than in 2017, but mail-in ballots may boost overall numbers.
description: Voter turnout in Germany  — as a measure of the  people visiting polling stations — was down on Sunday when compared to the last election in 2017, officials said. But the number is misleading. Participation could be extraordinarily high once mail-in ballots are counted.
content: Voter turnout in Germany  — as a measure of the  people visiting polling stations — was down on Sunday when compared to the last election in 2017, officials said. But the number is misleading. Participation could be extraordinarily high once mail-in ballots are counted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Known for Feuding With Immigrants, a TV Star Wants to Run a Town Many Call Home
description: A mayoral bid by a TV commentator known for her inflammatory messaging on race raises a larger question: How should Portugal address its colonial legacy?
content: AMADORA, Portugal — She is a former TV commentator whose penchant for provocation has won her fame, or at least notoriety, in Portugal: for instance, by describing calls for racial justice traitorous, and by referring to Black Portuguese by an old-fashioned term that translates to something like “Negro.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
title: Women Enslaved by ISIS Say They Did Not Consent to a Film About Them
description: The acclaimed documentary “Sabaya” portrays the rescue of Yazidi women sexually enslaved by the Islamic State terrorist group. But many of the traumatized women said they never agreed to be in the film.
content: In a critically acclaimed documentary on the rescue of women and girls sexually enslaved by ISIS, tension-filled scenes play out in a Syrian detention camp and later in a safe house where victims are faced with agonizing choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: The N.B.A. denies Andrew Wiggins’s request for a religious exemption from the vaccine.
description: Unless he gets vaccinated, Mr. Wiggins will be barred from attending home games in San Francisco, where his team is based.
content: The N.B.A. has denied the request of Andrew Wiggins, a Golden State Warriors player, for a religious exemption from the coronavirus vaccine, which is required in San Francisco to attend large indoor events, including Warriors home games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Ancient Greece Through the Lens of the Camera Obscura
description: Vera Lutter evaded wildfires and sacrificed meals and sleep to produce beguiling photographs with an archaic form of image-making.
content: In early August, when The Times Magazine reached out to the photographer Vera Lutter about documenting ancient Athenian ruins, she was in her native Germany mourning her father, who died this summer. At the time, European news had been dominated by reports of wildfires in Greece — an ill omen for the clear skies and uphill hikes required to shoot atop the Acropolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Germany’s election is neck and neck.
content: Early exit polls showed a tight race after Germans voted on a new Parliament. Their choice will determine who succeeds Chancellor Angela Merkel at the helm of the E.U.’s most populous democracy. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea will start giving vaccine boosters amid a surge in Covid cases.
description: The country has seen a spike in infections after Chuseok, a three-day holiday celebrating the fall harvest.
content: The Prime Minister of South Korea said on Sunday that the nation would soon start administering booster shots to medical workers and people in their 60s and older, as the country battled a new wave of infections after a national holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Melissa Eddy and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: These are the leading candidates for the chancellery.
description: In Germany, political parties name their candidates for chancellor before campaigning begins.
content: In Germany, political parties name their candidates for chancellor before campaigning begins, and most of the focus falls on the selections who have a realistic chance of winning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Lois Smith is the oldest performer to win a Tony.
description: Lois Smith, 90, is at last a Tony winner. And not just a winner — she is now the oldest performer to win a Tony Award for acting.
content: Lois Smith, 90, is at last a Tony winner. And not just a winner — she is now the oldest performer to win a Tony Award for acting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: At Black-owned funeral homes, many staffers are burying their own colleagues.
description: “We mourn, we comfort, we are in pain, too,” said Hari P. Close, the president of the National Funeral Directors & Morticians Association.
content: For Black-owned funeral businesses, the pain of the coronavirus pandemic has been two-pronged: Many funeral workers are mourning their own colleagues who have died from the virus, all while experiencing burnout from having to preside over countless services for their Black patrons and neighbors who have died at disproportionate rates from Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mohamed Hussein Tantawi, 85, Dies; Led Egypt After Mubarak’s Fall
description: A general and defense minister, he took power after the Arab Spring uprising, overseeing a crackdown on pro-democracy protesters.
content: Mohamed Hussein Tantawi, the Egyptian general who took charge of the country when Hosni Mubarak was forced to step down amid the 2011 Arab Spring uprising, died on Tuesday. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Abaluck, Laura H. Kwong and Stephen P. Luby
title: We Did the Research: Masks Work, and You Should Choose a High Quality Mask if Possible
description: One of the largest studies to date shows masks work.
content: Masks, especially surgical ones, substantially reduce the risk of getting Covid-19. Getting more people to wear them — through mandates or strategies like handing out masks at churches and other public events — could save thousands of lives each day globally and hundreds each day in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Voting ends in Germany in a tight race.
description: The voting is done, and exit polling throughout the day has suggested that the Social Democrats and the Christian Democratic Union are very close.
content: The polls have now closed in Germany, where voters have been casting their ballots for a new Parliament, which will ultimately determine who succeeds Chancellor Angela Merkel at the helm of the European Union’s most populous democracy after 16 years in office.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 26, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 26, 2021.
content: An article this weekend on Page 11 about Mo Abudu, the head of EbonyLife Media, describes incorrectly the status of more than 30 deals between Abudu’s media company and others. Some of those deals have been made public; they were not all unreported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Mendacity of Joe Biden
description: No White House fact sheet about other policies that benefited Black people can hide the fact that Haitian migrants at the southern border were treated like animals.
content: Joe Biden, once again, disappointed many of the same Black voters who were his strongest supporters. How much of this can or should Black people stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Elsie Chen
title: New Limits Give Chinese Video Gamers Whiplash
description: China has a complex relationship with video games. New government rules for minors have made it even more so.
content: China’s video game industry is booming. But it sure doesn’t feel that way to Stone Shi, a game designer in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: For Schumer and Pelosi, the Challenge of a Career With No Margin for Error
description: The top two Democrats in Congress face a daunting pile of legislative imperatives. With President Biden’s agenda hanging in the balance and few votes to spare, can they get it done?
content: WASHINGTON — Last week, as all outward appearances suggested gridlock on Capitol Hill, Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, and Speaker Nancy Pelosi were in perpetual motion, grasping to salvage their $3.5 trillion social policy and climate change bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Mark Morris Dance Group Debuts ‘Water’ in Its Element
description: Also on the bill for this free outdoor program is the choreographer’s U.S. premiere of “Quad,” a wordless television play by Samuel Beckett.
content: To make a dance to some of Handel’s “Water Music” and title it simply “Water” is just the kind of joke you would expect from Mark Morris. So is staging that work in Brooklyn Bridge Park with New York Harbor as the backdrop, putting “Water” right up against the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Booster Shots, Germany, Britney Spears: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tensions Flare in Ryder Cup as the U.S. Team Takes a Commanding Lead
description: The Americans were calmly overpowering the European side, but then things got testy.
content: HAVEN, Wis. — Golf is a game of decorum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: So organized it’s chaos: A German election primer.
description: Here’s a brief explainer on Germany’s vote.
content: It has been said that Germans are sometimes so organized that chaos reigns. Germany’s election system is no exception. It is so complex that even many Germans don’t understand it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
title: Five Years After Peace Deal, Colombia Is Running Out of Time, Experts Say
description: A treaty with rebels in 2016 called for the end of a decades-long war. But that is not the same as achieving peace, and the window for doing so may be closing.
content: LA PAZ, Colombia — On a coca farm hidden in the jungle, a half-dozen day laborers slip out of hammocks and head to work, harvesting the shiny green leaves that will become cocaine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Five Killed in West Bank Shootouts
description: The Israeli military said the five were killed during raids to arrest members of a Hamas network planning terrorist attacks against Israeli civilians.
content: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces killed five Palestinians in armed confrontations in the occupied West Bank early on Sunday, according to Israeli officials. They said the gun battles occurred during a series of raids intended to thwart a terrorist attack on Israeli civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: New Mexico health officials link misuse of ivermectin to two Covid-19 deaths.
description: Calls to poison control centers have soared across the country as misinformation spreads touting the anti-parasite drug as a Covid treatment.
content: A wave of misinformation touting the deworming drug ivermectin as a Covid treatment appears to be showing no signs of abating, with calls about the drug to poison control centers surging, and officials in New Mexico saying misuse of the medication contributed to at least two deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard, Grace Ashford and Neil Vigdor
title: These Health Care Workers Would Rather Get Fired Than Get Vaccinated
description: Monday is the vaccination deadline for New York State health care workers. Thousands of refusers have failed to meet it.
content: Deborah Conrad, a physician assistant in western New York, and Simmone Leslie, a hospital switchboard operator in Queens, have both worked long, risky hours during the pandemic. But now, both are prepared to lose their jobs rather than meet Monday’s state deadline for health care workers to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Francesco Risso on Rethinking the Fashion Show
description: After almost two years of social distancing, the Marni creative director had had enough. So he dressed all 500 of his guests in Milan this week.
content: Francesco Risso has been creative director at Marni since 2016, mixing the Milanese fashion house’s explosive prints and prim but off-kilter silhouettes with his own bold and often playful aesthetic. On Saturday, 18 months after Marni’s last physical runway show, the onetime protégé of Miuccia Prada upped the ante yet again with an experimental live event. Here, he explains why.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Slipping Into the Cool Water Always Feels Like Slipping Back in Time’
description: A bittersweet last day of summer, a late-night song in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noele Illien
title: Swiss Voters Approve Law Allowing Same-Sex Marriages
description: The legislation, endorsed in a referendum, will also allow same-sex couples to use sperm banks and to adopt children for the first time.
content: ZURICH — Voters in Switzerland overwhelmingly decided on Sunday to legalize same-sex marriage, making the country one of the last in Western Europe to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Jagged Little Pill’ arrives with 15 Tony nominations, but also intensifying controversy.
description: The musical, featuring Alanis Morissette songs, is planning to resume performances on Broadway next month.
content: “Jagged Little Pill” barrels into tonight’s Tony Awards with 15 nominations, more than any other show — but also with its producers confronting two controversies that have prompted scrutiny and an apology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees Pull Even With the Red Sox as Stanton Leads the Way
description: A pair of wins in Boston, both powered by Giancarlo Stanton, has the rival teams tied for the A.L.’s top wild-card spot.
content: BOSTON — After meandering through most of September, the Yankees’ season has reached a make-or-break point. Over the final week and a half of the regular season, they have six games scheduled against two of the teams — the Boston Red Sox and Toronto Blue Jays — they are fighting with for the final two postseason spots in the American League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: She Bought Her Dream Home. Then a ‘Sovereign Citizen’ Changed the Locks.
description: A New Jersey woman was preyed upon by a fast-growing extremist group that claims its members are sovereign Moors, not bound by U.S. laws.
content: The official-looking letters started arriving soon after Shanetta Little bought the cute Tudor house on Ivy Street in Newark. Bearing a golden seal, in aureate legalistic language, the documents claimed that an obscure 18th-century treaty gave the sender rights to claim her new house as his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Jonathan Mirsky, Journalist and Historian of China, Dies at 88
description: He brought a historian’s expertise to many decades of writing about China for The Observer of London, The New York Review of Books and other outlets.
content: Jonathan Mirsky, who brought a historian’s expertise to many decades of writing about China, notably as a correspondent for The Observer of London during the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989 and as a longtime contributor to The New York Review of Books, died on Sept. 5 at his home in London. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Looks From The Tony Awards
description: See all of the stars as they go down the carpet.
content: See all of the stars as they go down the carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Amtrak Derailment in Montana Leaves At Least 3 Dead
description: The authorities said at least three people were killed and 50 others were injured in a derailment involving eight cars of an Empire Builder train near Joplin, Mont.
content: The authorities said at least three people were killed and 50 others were injured in a derailment involving eight cars of an Empire Builder train near Joplin, Mont.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Why Was Vicha Ratanapakdee Killed?’
description: His death helped awaken the nation to a rise in anti-Asian violence. For his grieving family, the reckoning hasn’t gone far enough.
content: Throughout 2020, multiple strangers came at Monthanus Ratanapakdee seemingly out of nowhere. An old man yelled at her in Golden Gate Park — something about a virus and going back to her country. When she discussed these incidents, her father would ask, “Is it really that bad?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Melissa Clark’s pepperoni pasta with lemon and garlic is a perfect weeknight meal or Sunday dinner.
content: Good morning. Time was, Sundays were so different from the other days: long and relaxed and contemplative, a chance to recuperate from the toil of the week, hopefully in the kitchen. I’d make like Marcella Hazan and simmer a Bolognese for the better part of an afternoon, make yogurt for the week to come, roast a chicken or a turkey breast for sandwiches, bake a visiting cake to take to co-workers on Monday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Antibody Treatments: Paying for Anti-Vaxxers’ Irresponsibility
description: Antivaxxers and antibodies; a false health care choice; recalling an abortion; wild animals in national parks; whitewashing Jan. 6.
content: To the Editor:
